query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
1 In su l’estremità d’un’alta ripa 2 che facevan gran pietre rotte in cerchio, 3 venimmo sopra più crudele stipa;
4 e quivi, per l’orribile soperchio 5 del puzzo che ’l profondo abisso gitta, 6 ci raccostammo, in dietro, ad un coperchio
7 d’un grand’ avello, ov’ io vidi una scritta 8 che dicea: ‘Anastasio papa guardo, 9 lo qual trasse Fotin de la via dritta’.

Please translate literally into English.
10 «Lo nostro scender conviene esser tardo, 11 sì che s’ausi un poco in prima il senso 12 al tristo fiato; e poi no i fia riguardo».
query.result: 10 “Our descent must be slow, 11 so that our senses may grow somewhat accustomed 12 to the foul stench; and then we will not care”.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
13 Così ’l maestro; e io «Alcun compenso», 14 dissi lui, «trova che ’l tempo non passi 15 perduto». Ed elli: «Vedi ch’a ciò penso».
query.result: 13 Thus the master; and I said to him, “Find some way 14 that the time may not pass wasted”. And he: “See that I am thinking about that”.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
16 «Figliuol mio, dentro da cotesti sassi», 17 cominciò poi a dir, «son tre cerchietti 18 di grado in grado, come que’ che lassi.
query.result: 16 “My son, within these rocks”, 17 he then began to say, “are three circles 18 of descending order, like those you left.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
19 Tutti son pien di spirti maladetti; 20 ma perché poi ti basti pur la vista, 21 intendi come e perché son costretti.

Please translate literally into English.
22 D’ogne malizia, ch’odio in cielo acquista, 23 ingiuria è ’l fine, ed ogne fin cotale 24 o con forza o con frode altrui contrista.
query.result: 22 Of all malice, which acquires hatred in heaven, 23 injury is the end, and every such end 24 either by force or by fraud works another’s harm.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
25 Ma perché frode è de l’uom proprio male, 26 più spiace a Dio; e però stan di sotto 27 li frodolenti, e più dolor li assale.
query.result: 25 But because fraud is man’s own particular evil, 26 it displeases God more; and therefore the fraudulent 27 stand below, and greater pain assails them.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
28 Di vïolenti il primo cerchio è tutto; 29 ma perché si fa forza a tre persone, 30 in tre gironi è distinto e costrutto.

Please translate literally into English.
31 A Dio, a sé, al prossimo si pòne 32 far forza, dico in loro e in lor cose, 33 come udirai con aperta ragione.
query.result: 31 Force can be done to God, to oneself, to one’s neighbor, 32 I say to them and to their belongings, 33 as you will hear with clear reasoning.

34 Violent death and grievous wounds 35 are inflicted on one’s neighbor, and on his belongings 36 ruin, fires, and harmful thefts;
37 whence murderers and everyone who smites evilly, 38 ravagers and plunderers, all are tormented 39 in the first ring in different bands.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
40 Puote omo avere in sé man vïolenta 41 e ne’ suoi beni; e però nel secondo 42 giron convien che sanza pro si penta
43 qualunque priva sé del vostro mondo, 44 biscazza e fonde la sua facultade, 45 e piange là dov’ esser de’ giocondo.
query.result:
40 A man can lay violent hands on himself 41 and on his own goods; and therefore in the second 42 ring it is necessary that he repent without avail
43 whoever deprives himself of your world, 44 squanders and wastes his wealth, 45 and weeps there where he should be joyful.

46 Force can be done to the deity, 47 by denying and blaspheming it in one’s heart, 48 and by scorning nature and its goodness;
49 and therefore the smallest ring 50 seals with its mark Sodom and Cahors 51 and whoever, scorning God in his heart, speaks.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
52 La frode, ond’ ogne coscïenza è morsa, 53 può l’omo usare in colui che ’n lui fida 54 e in quel che fidanza non imborsa.
query.result: 52 Fraud, by which every conscience is bitten, 53 a man can practice on one who trusts in him 54 and on one who does not harbor trust.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
55 Questo modo di retro par ch’incida 56 pur lo vinco d’amor che fa natura; 57 onde nel cerchio secondo s’annida
58 ipocresia, lusinghe e chi affattura, 59 falsità, ladroneccio e simonia, 60 ruffian, baratti e simile lordura.
query.result:
55 This latter mode seems to cut 56 only the bond of love that nature makes; 57 whence in the second circle nestle
58 hypocrisy, flattery, and those who practice witchcraft, 59 falsehood, theft, and simony, 60 pimps, barrators, and similar filth.

61 By the other mode that love is forgotten 62 that nature makes, and that which is then added, 63 from which special trust is created;
64 whence in the smallest circle, where is the point 65 of the universe on which Dis sits, 66 whoever betrays is eternally consumed».

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
67 E io: «Maestro, assai chiara procede 68 la tua ragione, e assai ben distingue 69 questo baràtro e ’l popol ch’e’ possiede.
query.result: 67 And I: “Master, your reasoning proceeds quite clearly, 68 and distinguishes quite well 69 this abyss and the people that it possesses.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
70 Ma dimmi: quei de la palude pingue, 71 che mena il vento, e che batte la pioggia, 72 e che s’incontran con sì aspre lingue,
73 perché non dentro da la città roggia 74 sono ei puniti, se Dio li ha in ira? 75 e se non li ha, perché sono a tal foggia?».
query.result:
70 But tell me: those of the sticky marsh, 71 that the wind drives and the rain beats, 72 and who clash with such harsh tongues,
73 why are they not punished inside the red city, 74 if God is angry with them? 75 and if he is not, why are they in such a state?».

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
76 Ed elli a me «Perché tanto delira», 77 disse, «lo ’ngegno tuo da quel che sòle? 78 o ver la mente dove altrove mira?
79 Non ti rimembra di quelle parole 80 con le quai la tua Etica pertratta 81 le tre disposizion che ’l ciel non vole,
82 incontenenza, malizia e la matta 83 bestialitade? e come incontenenza 84 men Dio offende e men biasimo accatta?
85 Se tu riguardi ben questa sentenza, 86 e rechiti a la mente chi son quelli 87 che sù di fuor sostegnon penitenza,
88 tu vedrai ben perché da questi felli 89 sien dipartiti, e perché men crucciata 90 la divina vendetta li martelli».
query.result:
76 And he to me: “Why does your intellect wander so far”, 77 he said, “from what it usually does? 78 or is your mind looking elsewhere?
79 Don’t you remember those words 80 with which your Ethics discusses 81 the three dispositions that Heaven does not want,
82 incontinence, malice, and mad 83 bestiality? and how incontinence 84 offends God less and incurs less blame?
85 If you consider this judgment well, 86 and recall to your mind who those are 87 who endured punishment up above,
88 you will see clearly why from these wicked ones 89 they are separated, and why divine vengeance 90 torments them less”.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
91 «O sol che sani ogne vista turbata, 92 tu mi contenti sì quando tu solvi, 93 che, non men che saver, dubbiar m’aggrata.
query.result: 91 “O sun that heals every troubled sight, 92 you satisfy me so when you solve, 93 that, no less than knowing, doubting pleases me.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
94 Ancora in dietro un poco ti rivolvi», 95 diss’ io, «là dove di’ ch’usura offende 96 la divina bontade, e ’l groppo solvi».
query.result: 94 “Turn back a little further”, 95 I said, “to where you say that usury offends 96 divine goodness, and untie the knot”.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
97 «Filosofia», mi disse, «a chi la ’ntende, 98 nota, non pure in una sola parte, 99 come natura lo suo corso prende
100 dal divino ’ntelletto e da sua arte; 101 e se tu ben la tua Fisica note, 102 tu troverai, non dopo molte carte,
103 che l’arte vostra quella, quanto pote, 104 segue, come ’l maestro fa ’l discente; 105 sì che vostr’ arte a Dio quasi è nepote.
query.result:
97 “Philosophy”, he said to me, “to one who understands it, 98 notes, not just in one part alone, 99 how nature takes its course
100 from the divine intellect and from its art; 101 and if you note your Physics well, 102 you will find, not many pages in,
103 that your art follows that of nature, as much as it can, 104 as the student follows the master; 105 so that your art is, as it were, God’s grandchild.

106 From these two, if you recall 107 the beginning of Genesis, it is necessary 108 to take one’s life and advance the race;
109 and because the usurer takes another path, 110 he scorns nature for itself and for its follower, 111 since he places his hope in something else.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
112 Ma seguimi oramai che ’l gir mi piace; 113 ché i Pesci guizzan su per l’orizzonta, 114 e ’l Carro tutto sovra ’l Coro giace,
115 e ’l balzo via là oltra si dismonta».
query.result:
112 But follow me now, for the circuit pleases me; 113 for the Pisces are darting up the horizon, 114 and the Wain lies entirely over the Chorus,
115 and the cliff is descended over there beyond”.
